newsitem.title: USA: Internet offers promise for secure document delivery.
newsitem.headline: Internet offers promise for secure document delivery.

text.p: The Internet may soon become the speediest means of secure document distribution if a Silicon Valley start-up company's new product takes off.

The start-up, Tumbleweed Software Inc., Monday formally released its document delivery software -- Tumbleweed Posta -- which it said can be used to deliver formatted and encoded documents over the Internet.
The software also enables documents to be sent to fax machines and other devices and allows senders to track document delivery and confirm receipt.

In an interview ahead of Monday's formal launch, Jeff Smith, president and chief executive officer of Tumbleweed, said, "This is a new market. We're the first ones that are shipping a product for this market."

Posta will be available immediately in North America and is due to ship internationally by the end of October. A kit with network computer software and licenses for 20 users or accounts is $3,999, and additional users cost $189 each.

Due to the minimal cost of sending messages on the Internet, the services are expected to be far cheaper than the $10 or more for domestic U.S. overnight packages. Security, however, has been a major concern for businesses and individuals because of the Internet's transparency.

Tumbleweed's business model is twofold. Large organizations can pay for the software upfront to deploy it, or service companies will deploy it for customers, charging on a monthly or by-transaction basis.

Smith estimates it may cost as little as 10 cents to 15 cents per delivery for those who choose to charge on a transactional basis, or $10 to $15 a month as a value-added service to Internet subscribers.
Some companies -- from The New York Times and law firms to accountants and Internet service providers like Netcom OnLine Communication Inc. -- have evaluated the Tumbleweed product.

United Parcel Service has begun evaluating electronic document delivery and Last week announced it has agreed to test a rival Internet document delivery system being developed by Netdox Inc., a private company owned by consultants Deloitte & Touche USA LLP and the Thurston Group.

Federal Express Corp, which may face the greatest threat from electronic document delivery, itself tried to launch a direct delivery product recently with its Zapmail service, which has failed to catch on.

The U.S. Postal Services has also been talking about getting into the electronic document distribution game and Pitney Bowes Inc., a leading supplier of postage machines, has been trying out Tumbleweed's product.
